Graphical abstract The zeolite-containing Ru/MnCO3 3Ru(NO)-Mn catalysts were investigated on the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) in a low pressure fixed-bed reactor. The catalytic activity and i/n ratio of C4 hydrocarbons were found to be a little higher than those of non-zeolite systems such as 3Ru(NO)-Mn alone and 3Ru(NO)-Mn with MnCO3 as a diluents, while the α-value and olefin/paraffin ratio of C2–C4 hydrocarbons were lower for the zeolite system than those of non-zeolite. The hydrocarbon cracking ability could be improved for all-in-one type Ru-Z-B as well as 3Ru(NO)-Mn physically mixed with zeolite, compared with 3Ru(NO)-Mn with MnCO3. In fact, the Ru-Z-B catalyst gives a narrower carbon distribution than the 3Ru(NO)-Mn with MnCO3 catalyst. The Ru crystallite sizes of used catalysts after 120h- and 720h-reaction were close to those of fresh catalysts, indicating no aggregation occurred. The origin of catalyst deactivation could depend on the extent of hydrocarbon deposition, even in zeolite-containing catalyst systems. The longer reaction time, the more condensed wax materials were formed and, even after a gentle calcination of the used Ru-Z-B catalyst at 350°C, the inorganic-like carbons still remain, as ascertained by TPR-Q-mass analysis. The proposed deactivation mechanism would be consistent with other analytical evidences such as thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), CO adsorption, transmission electron micrograph (TEM) of used catalysts as well as NH3-TPD of the used zeolites. Keywords Fischer–Tropsch synthesis Zeolite-containing Ru catalyst Narrow carbon distribution Deactivation 1 Introduction Biomass has recently received increased attention as one potential source of renewable energy [1]. Among all biomass conversion processes, the BTL (biomass to liquid) process is one of the most promising ways to utilize biomass in remote and/or local areas to form sulfur-free jet fuels [2]. The development of high-performance catalysts for the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis is one of the key technologies required for the small-scale BTL process of ca. 100t/d of biomass resources, which are approximately 1/100-scale of gas-to-liquid (GTL) process. Ruthenium is known to be the most active metal for this reaction. Indeed, higher CO/H2 conversion levels, hydrocarbon productivities, and chain growth probabilities can be achieved when using Ru-based catalysts [3–5]. Industrial output of ruthenium is ca. 1/2000 of that of cobalt and metal cost of Ru is approximately 4–5 times that of Co metal [6], while space–time-yield in FT reaction by Ru catalyst is, at least, 3–5 times higher that of Co catalyst [7,8]. Hydrocarbon productivity per Ru or Co metal cost could be almost the same. As opposed to iron, ruthenium catalysts have been found not to be negatively affected by product water [9–12] and other oxygenate-containing atmosphere, which is an important requisite to successfully convert biomass-derived syngas into hydrocarbons [12,13], since no formation of inactive ruthenium oxides would occur [9,13]. So, we believe, taking catalyst regeneration into account, Ru-based small-scale BTL process seems probable. A crucial factor for catalyst deactivation during Ru-based FTS reaction could come mainly from formation of carbonaceous materials. In this point, the Ru system would differ from cobalt catalyst, in which the deactivation of cobalt catalysts is mainly due to the oxidation of cobalt metal and growth of metal cobalt [14–17]. In fact, we have investigated on the origin of catalyst deactivation in terms of the extent of hydrocarbon deposition. The adsorbed atomic carbon at the peak temperature around 250–350°C was eliminated by H2 treatment, but the more heavy hydrocarbons at peak temperature over 400°C such as polymeric and graphitic carbons were difficult to be removed by some treatment [18]. It is known that the use of an acidic zeolite as a co-catalyst in combination with the conventional FT catalyst can lead to an improvement of gasoline-range hydrocarbon selectivity owing to the hydrocracking of heavier FT products over the acid sites [19–21]. In these catalytic systems, the primary hydrocarbon products formed on the active FT catalyst can migrate into the micropores of zeolites, where the hydrocracking occurs, and the products may diffuse out of the micropores. Thus, we may expect that the presence of zeolite materials causes heavy hydrocarbon to be decomposed, which could lead to prevent wax accumulation as well as a preferential formation of gasoline-range hydrocarbons by in situ upgrading. In our previous study, we found that the addition of Mn to γ-Al2O3 enhanced the removal of chloride from RuCl3, which can lead to the formation of metallic Ru with moderate particle size, which would be active for the FT reaction [22,23]. Also, RuCl3 catalysts supported on MnO have been effective for the FT reaction with low methane productivity and high olefin selectivity [24]. At next stage, the ruthenium nitrate/MnCO3 catalyst has been found instead of RuCl3-based catalyst, because of a high cost of waste water treatment containing Cl− ion [18]. Thus, the aim of the present study is to examine the effect of zeolite as co-catalyst on the activity of fixed-bed FTS reaction using ruthenium nitrate/MnCO3 and to shed light on the nature of accumulated hydrocarbons in the presence of zeolite. The temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) methods [25] equipped with a quadrupole mass spectrometer (Q-Mass) is used for detection of gaseous products, in order to discriminate carbonaceous materials on the catalyst surface. Now we report on the catalyst nature of Ru/MnCO3 and zeolite system for the FT reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Manganese carbonate (MnCO3) and ruthenium nitrosyl nitrate [Ru(NO3)3(NO)] were commercially available and Ru/MnCO3 catalysts were prepared by kneading MnCO3 support and silica sol as binder with [Ru(NO3)3(NO)], followed by extruding to make pellet shape and drying at 80°C [26]. The Ru content was 3wt%. These are denoted as 3Ru(NO)-Mn. Zeolite materials such as H-ZSM-5, H-MOR, H-Beta are purchased from Zeolyst Co. Ltd. Ru-Z-B catalysts were prepared by kneading 3Ru(NO)-Mn, H-ZSM-5 (80) and boehmite as binder, where the weight ratio is 18/72/10, followed by extruding to make pellet shape. Both pellet sizes are 1mm diameter and 5mm long. As shown in Fig. 1 , both 3Ru(NO)-Mn and zeolite pellets are physically mixed and put them inside reactor, while both Ru-Z-B put inside reactor with diluent. The surface area is 162.1m2/g for 3Ru(NO)-Mn and 192.4m2/g for Ru-Z-B and pore volumes are 0.356cm3/g and 0.301cm3/g, while average pore diameters are 8.78nm and 6.25nm, as shown in Table 1 . For comparison, Ru-Mn/H-ZSM-5catalyst was prepared using impregnation method, where [Mn(NO3)2·6H2O] was impregnated with H-ZSM-5, followed by dryness and calcination at 600°C and then [Ru(NO3)3(NO)] was impregnated with Mn/H-ZSM-5, accompanied by dryness and calcinations at 300°C. In this case, the Ru content was also 3wt%. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of the fresh catalysts were recorded using a MAC Science MPX-18 diffractometer with Cu-Kα irradiation, operated at 40kV and 100mA. The reducibility of the prepared catalysts was studied by H2-temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) instrument. Before the analysis, 50mg of sample in a quartz tube was purged with He at 200°C for 1h in order to remove the impurities on the surface of the catalyst. After the sample was cooled to room temperature in flowing He, TPR was carried out using 5% H2/Ar (v/v) mixture with a flow rate of 30ml/min at a heating rate of 5°C/min from room temperature to 750°C and the H2 consumption was recorded with a TCD. The reducibility of FT wax over the used catalysts was also studied by TPR method. In this case, after a similar pretreatment, the H2 consumption was recorded with a quadrupole mass spectrometer (Q-Mass). BET surface area and BJH (Barett–Joyner–Halenda) pore size distributions of all the catalysts were determined by N2-physisorption using BELSORP MAX apparatus (Nippon Bell Co. Ltd.) at liquid-N2 temperature at −196°C. The dispersion and crystallite size of the reduced ruthenium particles were measured by CO chemisorption methods, which were carried out by using the BEL-CAT apparatus. Before chemisorption of CO, the catalysts (50mg) were pretreated in He for 35min and then reduced for 30min in a 5% H2/Ar gas flow of 50ml/min and in He for 15min at 400°C in a reaction chamber. After this pretreatment, the samples were cooled down at 50°C under He gas flow and CO pulse measurements were carried out using 5% CO/He gas flow of 50ml/min. Finally, Ru crystallite size was determined from CO pulse data. NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments were carried out for fresh and used zeolites, separated from zeolite physically mixed with Ru(NO) catalyst, on a special NH3-TPD apparatus (BELCAT, Nippon Bel), which was connected to a TCD detector for measuring the solid acidity of the catalysts. After pretreatment under He flow at 500°C for 60min, adsorption of NH3 at 100°C for 90min, and desorption of the weakly adsorbed NH3 under He flow at 100°C for 30min, TPD profiles were recorded under He flow between 100°C and 800°C (heating rate: 10°C/min). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of used catalysts (after 120h- and 720h-reactions) was carried out by using TG 2000, Bruker AXS. The FT used catalyst of ∼10mg was heated from 30 to 800°C with a ramping rate of 10°C/min under an air flow rate of 30ml/min and the weight loss of used catalyst was recorded. Transmission electron micrograph (TEM) analyses were also carried out on the fresh and used FT catalysts by using TEM (TECNAI F20 instrument) analysis operating at 200kv to verify the crystallite size of ruthenium. The fresh samples were pretreated with 2MPa of H2 at 200C for 5h. The used catalysts were measured after washing with n-hexane at 60°C to remove the adsorbed hydrocarbons. A lot of metallic particles were observed over the catalysts. The average crystallite size (d) of Ru was estimated using the equation of d = ∑ i n i d i 3 / ∑ i n i d i 2 ( n i : number of the particles ; d i : crystallite size ) . 2.3 FT reaction The catalyst (1g) and zeolite or diluent (6g) were introduced into a quartz-type fixed bed reactor with an inner diameter of 10mm and a length of 300mm, equipped with high pressure trap kept at 100°C to remove heavy hydrocarbons and water formed during FT reaction before analyzing the effluent gas. Prior to FT reaction, fresh catalyst was pretreated by reduction with 1MPa of H2 at 230°C for 10h. After reduction, CO/H2 gas containing 10% N2 was introduced into the catalyst bed. The typical reaction conditions were H2/CO/N2 =6/3/1, T =260°C, P =1.0MPa. The on-line gas chromatography (GC) was equipped with Porapak Q and MS 5A columns for the TCD detector for inorganic gases (H2, CO, CH4 and N2) and CP-Al2O3/KCl PLOT capillary column for FID detector for C1–C4 hydrocarbons and DB-1 capillary column for another FID detector for C5–C10 hydrocarbons. From on-line TCD and FID analyses, CO conversion and C5+ selectivity were estimated. Here, C5+ selectivity was estimated according to the equation C5+ selectivity=100−(C1 −C4 hydrocarbons+CO2). After the reaction, liquid product was collected and analyzed by another off-line FID gas-chromatography using UA-DX30 capillary column, in order to estimate chain growth probability (α). CO conversion and C5+ selectivity were estimated using nitrogen internal standard. The value of C5+ selectivity obtained by on-line GC analysis was in accordance with the value from liquid product analysis after reaction. The used catalysts were obtained after 120h- and 720h-reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characteristics of the fresh FTS catalysts The physicochemical properties such as surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter of three FT catalysts after calcination were summarized in Table 1. The surface area was found to be in the range of 91.1 and 192m2/g and an average pore size of 6.25 and 8.78nm and the pore volume was found to be 0.163–0.35cm3/g on the FT catalysts. The surface area of MnCO3 support was found to be 109m2/g and an average pore diameter is of 12.2nm, while the surface areas of zeolite families were between 305 and 630m2/g and an average pore diameter is 2.38–4.11nm. Thus, with the addition of ruthenium precursors to MnCO3, the surface area was increased, while the pore diameter was decreased and the pore volume was constant, as can be seen from Table 1 (3Ru(NO)-Mn and Ru-Z-B). However, the surface area and pore volume of Ru and Mn-modifed zeolite (RuMn/Z) were found to be a little smaller than those of MnCO3-based catalyst: The order of surface area was Ru-Z-B (192m2/g)>3Ru(NO)-Mn (162m2/g)>MnCO3 (109m2/g)>RuMn/Z (91.1m2/g). These suggested an effective role of MnCO3 in the pore distribution on the catalyst surfaces [27]. The dispersion and crystallite size of ruthenium on the fresh FT catalysts were characterized by CO chemisorption method, as shown in Table 1. For these FT catalysts, the crystallite size of ruthenium was found to be in the range of 1.99–2.21nm and ruthenium dispersion was around 60.5–67.1%. These sizes were a little smaller than the suitable sizes of 6–8nm attributed to the high activity on FT reaction over Ru-Mn/γ-Al2O3 [23,28,29]. These slight irregularities of crystallite size would come from, at least in part, a difference in catalyst supports (Al2O3, MnCO3 and zeolite). In fact, in the Ru/Al2O3 catalyst, 5–8nm of Ru has been observed for suitable crystallite size [30], while the crystallite size of 1.8–3.2nm was obtained for Ru-Al-SBA-15 [31]. Fig. 2 showed characteristic reduction behavior of FT catalysts measured by TPR experiments. The TPR profile of 3Ru(NO)-Mn, dried at 80°C, was first analyzed and the observed data showed two characteristic reduction peaks and the first reduction peak at 247°C was responsible for the reduction of RuO2/RuOx to metallic ruthenium [32,33] and second weak peak at 440°C was attributed to the reduction of MnOx to metallic manganese [34]. The TPR profile of Ru-Z-B catalyst was similar to that of 3Ru(NO)-Mn and the reduction of RuO2/RuOx was observed at 249°C, but no MnO reduction peak was detected. From these data, Ru0 and MnOx would be main chemical states under reaction conditions. This assumption agreed with X-ray photoelectron spectra of Ru-Mn-γ-Al2O3 catalyst, as previous reported [35]. The reduction peak at 285°C was found to be a little higher for RuMn/Z than those of other two catalysts. The higher reduction temperature of RuMn/Z in this case was indicative of a strong interaction between Ru and zeolite support. This might arise from the hydroxyl groups present in zeolite. For Ru/CNT catalyst, an interaction of Ru ions with surface hydroxyl has been reported [36]. 3.2 Activities of physically mixed catalysts and all-in-one type catalyst (Ru-Z-B) The catalyst performances at 260°C on stream on FTS catalyst were summarized in Table 2 , where the average catalytic activities were given. For 3Ru(NO)-Mn catalyst, the CO conversions of 82.9% and 70.8% were higher for use of diluents such as MnCO3 and γ-Al2O3 than 61.6% without diluent. In the presence of zeolite families as co-catalyst, the CO conversion was further improved and the order was H-ZSM-5(50)(96.0%)>H-MOR(20)(92.9%)>H-USY(30)(90.5%) >H-Beta(28)(88.5%). On the contrary, the conversion of RuMn/Z with γ-Al2O3 was found to be 51.6% which is lower than those of any 3Ru(NO)-Mn system, being consistent with the results of reduction peak from TPR, as shown in Fig. 2. The conversion of all-in-one type Ru-Z-B catalyst was 29.7%, due to one-eleventh of 3Ru(NO)-Mn content those of other catalysts. The C5+ selectivity for 3Ru(NO)-Mn with diluent was 74.8% and 71.8%, being higher than 65.2% without diluent. For zeolite families, the C5+ selectivities of 47.5–69.7% were lower than those of Ru-diluent systems, except for Ru-Z-B (70.2%). As a result, the order of C5+ yield was H-MOR(20)*(63.6%)>H-Beta(28)*(61.7%)>γ-Al2O3*(59.5%)>MnCO3*(53.0%)>H-ZSM-5(50)*(49.1%)>H-USY(30)*(43.0%)>none*(40.2%)>RuMn/Z(30.2%)>Ru-Z-B(20.9%) (*3Ru(NO)-Mn was omitted). The CH4 selectivities for 3Ru(NO)-Mn with diluents were 4.5% and 6.0%, being lower than 13.0%without diluent. With zeolites, the selectivities were 6.7–7.6%, except for 18.0% for H-USY(30), but the selectivities were 12.9% and 9.11% for RuMn/Z and Ru-Z-B. The CO2 selectivities for zeolites were 5.4–8.9%, which were higher than those of non-zeolite systems (2.7–4.3%). Very low CO2 selectivities of 0.21–0.84% were obtained for RuMn/Z and Ru-Z-B. The α-values for zeolites systems (0.67–0.75) were slightly lower than for non-zeolites (0.79–0.84). For RuMn/Z, the value was 0.70, but, for Ru-Z-B, the value was 0.53. The O/(O+P) ratio for zeolite systems (0.0–0.10) were much lower than for non-zeolites (0.35–0.67). For RuMn/Z, the value was 0.48, but, for Ru-Z-B, the value was 0.36. On the contrary, the i/n ratio of zeolites systems were 0.55–1.68, being much higher than for non-zeolites (0.01–0.02), indicating that the olefin hydrogenation and isomerization were accelerated by zeolites as co-catalyst. Fig. 3 showed the time-courses of FT catalytic activities for 3Ru(NO)-Mn mixed with zeolites. As shown in Fig. 3a, the initial catalytic activities for 3Ru(NO)-Mn with H-ZSM-5(50) were 32.1% at 230°C, 98.4% at 260°C and 97.5% at 270°C. As the reaction proceeded, the conversion decreased to 20.5% after 20h, 96.4% after 44h, and 94.6% after 68h. Fig. 3b showed the result of time-on-stream of 3Ru(NO)-Mn with H-Beta(28) catalyst. The initial catalytic activities were 22.1% at 230°C, 95.0% at 260°C and 99.9% at 270°C. Then, the conversion decreased to 15.3% after 22h, 86.8% after 46h, and 85.6% after 69h. Fig. 3c showed the result of time-on-stream of 3Ru(NO)-Mn with H-MOR(20) catalyst. The initial catalytic activities were 41.5% at 230°C, 95.9% at 260°C and 97.4% at 270°C. Then, the conversion decreased to 23.3% after 20h, 89.7% after 44h, and 91.4% after 69h. Fig. 3d showed the result of time-on-stream of 3Ru(NO)-Mn with H-USY(30) catalyst. The initial catalytic activities were as high as 72.7% at 230°C, 97.0% at 260°C and 94.2% at 270°C. Then, the conversion decreased to 50.6% after 17h, 97.0% after 45h, and 79.2% after 72h. Deactivation behavior for Ru(NO) with H-ZSM-5(50) at 260–270°C would be a little more gentle than for other three zeolites. The difference between H-ZSM-5 and other zeolites would, at least in part, come from pore structure: The H-ZSM-5 has the three-dimensional structure without cages in channel intersections (10-membered ring) [37]. On the contrary, the other three zeolites such as USY, Beta and MOR, have a large-size 12-membered ring micropore with cages in channel intersection, which could more favor reaction inside channel [38] and, as a result, the coke formation of H-ZSM-5 was, possibly, a little lower than those of other three zeolite [39]. Fig. 4 showed the effect of H-ZSM-5/3Ru(NO)-Mn weight ratio on FT catalytic activities at 270°C. The CO conversion increased from 80.1% to 93.9% with the increase in the weight ratio from 0 to 6. The CH4 selectivities decreased from 18.3% to 10.3% with increase in the ratio, but thereafter, again increased to 21.5% at the ratio of 6. The C2–C4 selectivities and (i/n)C4 ratio gently increased with the increase in the weight ratio, while the α-value and O/(O + P) ratio decreased with the increase in the weight ratio. Thus, not only the activity, but also up-grading properties such as isomerization, cracking and olefin hydrogenation could be improved by the increased ratio of H-ZSM-5 to 3Ru(NO)-Mn. 3.3 Analyses of used catalysts and zeolites after 120h-reaction In our previous work, we have reported that the used 3Ru(NO)-Mn catalyst without zeolite conditions did not show aggregation of Ru particles before and after approximately 120h-reaction [18]. In this work, the 3Ru(NO)-Mn catalyst with zeolite after 120h-reaction was resolved into the 3Ru(NO)-Mn and zeolite. The used 3Ru(NO)-Mn was analyzed by CO adsorption and transmission electron micrograph (TEM). The used zeolite was analyzed by NH3-TPD. As shown in Table 1, from CO adsorption, the used metallic Ru dispersion was 91.9% and the Ru crystallite size was 1.45nm, being roughly close to that of fresh 3Ru(NO)-Mn catalyst and being consistent with the average crystallite size (d) of Ru from TEM data, by using the equation d = ∑ n i d i 3 / ∑ n i d i 2 ( n i : number of the particles ; d i : crystallite size ) , as shown in Table 1 and Fig. 5(a and b). Investigation of the CO adsorption and TEM data demonstrated that aggregation of Ru particle could not occur during 120h-FT reaction, even in the presence of zeolite. As shown in the last column of Table 1, from thermogravimetric (TG) analysis, the entire weight loss of used 3Ru(NO)-Mn was estimated as 221mgg−1, being close to those of 3Ru(NO)-Mn/γ-Al2O3 system (180–250mgg−1), indicating hydrocarbon deposition on the catalyst surface [18]. The kinds of adsorbed hydrocarbons are investigated by TPR experiment using quadrupole mass spectrometry (QMS). As shown in Fig. 6(a), where the 3Ru(NO)-Mn catalyst with zeolite after 120h-reaction was used, the peak areas were roughly divided by three temperature ranges. The first Ru reduction peak was below 200°C [18], as confirmed by H2O formation. At the second peak temperature around 200–300°C, large CH4 peak was observed with small C2H4, C2H6 and CO/CO2 peaks, which could be from adsorbed atomic carbon [17]. At the third peak temperature around 300–400°C, small CH4 peak with H2O peak was detected, which was, probably, from polymeric carbon peak [17]. For comparison, the TPR of used 3Ru(NO)-Mn and MnCO3 diluent after 120h-reaction was shown in Fig. 6(b). Three peak temperature ranges similar to 3Ru(NO)-Mn and zeolite system were observed, but there was a small difference at the CH4 peak intensity around 300–400°C. The relative CH4 intensity ratio of the third to the second was in the order: 3Ru(NO)-Mn with MnCO3(0.76)>3Ru(NO)-Mn with zeolite (0.23), indicating that a formation of polymeric carbon could be depressed by addition of zeolite. The NH3-TPD patterns of fresh and used zeolites were shown in Fig. 7(a)–(d) and two-stage desorption of NH3 was observed. The peak at 100–250°C (first peak) was to weak acid sites and the peak at 300–550°C (second peak) was to strong acidic sites [40]. Table 3 gave the number of acid sites of each zeolite expressed as mmol NH3 g−1, peak temperature and the used/fresh ratio [41]. The first peak temperature of each used zeolite was between 168°C and 206°C, which was roughly the same as that of the fresh zeolite. The used/fresh ratio of acid sites number of first peak was USY(30) (1.36)>Beta(28) (1.12)>ZSM(50) (0.96)>MOR(20) (0.69). The second peak temperatures of used MOR(20) and ZSM-5(50) slightly raised by 6°C and 13°C, compared with those of fresh catalysts, whereas the second peak temperature of USY(30) and Beta(28) decreased by 27°C and 5°C, compared with the fresh catalyst. The used/fresh ratio of acid sites number of second peak was Beta (28) (0.81)>ZSM-5(50) (0.67)>MOR(20) (0.56)>USY(30) (0.38). Thus, the total acid natures of used zeolites would still remain and the observation of XRD intensity ratio of used zeolites to fresh ones would be consistent with results of the acid natures. 4 Activity and deactivation of all-in-one type Ru-Z-B catalysts The Ru-Z-B catalyst (0.5g) contained 0.09g (18wt%) of 3Ru(NO)-Mn. As already shown in Table 2, the CO conversion is 29.7% and C5+ selectivity is 70.2%. The selectivities of Ru-Z-B catalyst were roughly close to those of physically mixed catalysts. The α-value for Ru-Z-B (0.53) was slightly lower than for physically mixed catalysts (0.67–0.80), while the O/(O + P) ratio for Ru-Z-B (0.36) was a little higher than for 3Ru(NO)-Mn with zeolites (0.00–0.16), but lower than for 3Ru(NO)-Mn with MnCO3 (0.67). These indicated that the hydrocarbon cracking ability could be improved for Ru-Z-B, with moderate olefin hydrogenation. The hydrocarbon distributions of Ru-Z-B and 3Ru(NO)-Mn with MnCO3 were compared in Fig. 8(a). The all-in-one-type Ru-Z-B catalyst gave a narrower distribution than the 3Ru(NO)-Mn with MnCO3 catalyst, because the waxy product closely migrating from the 3Ru(NO)-Mn FTS catalyst to the surface of zeolite catalysts was subject to secondary isomerization and hydrocracking, forming lighter hydrocarbons. The fractions in C5+ were shown in Fig. 8(b). The C5–C11 fraction of Ru-Z-B was found to be 48.4%, higher than 33.3% of 3Ru(NO)-Mn. Fig. 9 showed the time-course of catalytic activity for Ru-Z-B. The initial catalytic activity was 86.1% at 260°C And a sharp drop up to 77. 8% was observed after 20h. As a reaction proceeded for 720h, the conversion decreased to 48.6%. The initial CH4 selectivity was 9.72% and it increased to 13.3%, while the initial CO2 selectivity was 3.06% and it decreased to 0.83% after 720h. As shown in Table 1, from CO adsorption of the used Ru-Z-B after 720h, Ru dispersion was 97.6% and the Ru crystallite size was 1.37nm, being roughly close to that of the fresh catalyst (66.6% and 2.01nm), and being consistent with the average crystallite size (d) of Ru from TEM data, as shown in Table 1 and Fig. 5(c and d). Investigation of the CO adsorption and TEM data demonstrated that aggregation of Ru particle could not occur even after 720h-FT reaction, in the presence of zeolite. However, as shown in the Table 1, from TG analysis, the entire weight loss of used Ru-Z-B was estimated as 270mgg−1, being a little higher than that of used 3Ru(NO)-Mn (120h) (221mgg−1), indicating a possibility of a more condensed hydrocarbon deposition on the used Ru-Z-B (720h) surface than the used 3Ru(NO)-Mn (120h) [18]. The kinds of adsorbed hydrocarbons were again investigated by TPR experiment using QMS. As shown in Fig. 10 (a), where the Ru-Z-B catalyst after 720h-reaction was used, the peak areas were roughly divided by four temperature ranges. The first Ru reduction peak was below 200°C [18], as confirmed by H2O formation. At the second peak temperature around 200–400°C, large shoulder CH4 peak was observed with small C2H6 peak, which could be from adsorbed atomic carbon [18]. At the third peak temperature around 400–550°C, large CH4 peak with H2O and CO/CO2 peaks was detected, which was, probably, from polymeric carbon peak [18]. At the forth peak temperature around 550–650°C, small CH4 peak was detected with CO/CO2 peaks, which would be from a graphitic carbon. These results could be consistent with Bartholomew's report [17]. After a gentle calcination at 350°C for 2h using the used Ru-Z-B (720h) catalyst, TPR-QMS was measured. As shown in Fig. 10(b), at the third and forth peak temperature ranges, weak two CH4 peaks were detected at 400–550°C and at 550–650°C with the first Ru reduction peak around 200°C, but the second peak range disappeared. Investigation of these findings demonstrated that the longer reaction time, the more condensed wax materials were formed and indicated that, by a gentle calcination at 350°C, almost all the wax could be removed, but the inorganic-like carbons still remained. Further study is now underway to understand a relationship between reaction time and wax accumulation leading to a complete deactivation. 5 Conclusions The zeolite-containing Ru/MnCO3 catalysts were tested as FTS catalysts and characterized before and after reaction. The catalytic activity and i/n ratio of C4 hydrocarbons were found to be a little higher zeolite-containing catalysts than those of non-zeolite systems, whereas the α-value and olefin/paraffin ratio of C2–C4 hydrocarbons were lower for the zeolite systems than those of non-zeolite. The selectivities of all-in-one type Ru-Z-B catalyst were roughly close to those of physically mixed catalysts. The hydrocarbon cracking ability of the zeolite systems could be more improved than that of non-zeolite such as 3Ru(NO)-Mn with MnCO3. In fact, the Ru-Z-B catalyst gave a narrower distribution than the 3Ru(NO)-Mn with MnCO3 catalyst. The Ru particle sizes of used catalysts after 120h- and 720h-reaction were close to those of fresh catalysts, indicating no aggregation occurred. The origin of catalyst deactivation would depend on the extent of hydrocarbon deposition, even in zeolite-containing catalyst systems. The longer reaction time, the more condensed wax materials were formed. These deactivation mechanisms would be consistent with all analytical evidences such as TGA, TPR-QMS, CO adsorption, TEM and NH3-TPD of the used zeolites. coredata.dc:description: The zeolite-containing Ru/MnCO3 3Ru(NO)-Mn catalysts were investigated on the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) in a low pressure fixed-bed reactor. The catalytic activity and i/n ratio of C4 hydrocarbons were found to be a little higher than those of non-zeolite systems such as 3Ru(NO)-Mn alone and 3Ru(NO)-Mn with MnCO3 as a diluents, while the α-value and olefin/paraffin ratio of C2–C4 hydrocarbons were lower for the zeolite system than those of non-zeolite. The hydrocarbon cracking ability could be improved for all-in-one type Ru-Z-B as well as 3Ru(NO)-Mn physically mixed with zeolite, compared with 3Ru(NO)-Mn with MnCO3. In fact, the Ru-Z-B catalyst gives a narrower carbon distribution than the 3Ru(NO)-Mn with MnCO3 catalyst. The Ru crystallite sizes of used catalysts after 120h- and 720h-reaction were close to those of fresh catalysts, indicating no aggregation occurred. The origin of catalyst deactivation could depend on the extent of hydrocarbon deposition, even in zeolite-containing catalyst systems. The longer reaction time, the more condensed wax materials were formed and, even after a gentle calcination of the used Ru-Z-B catalyst at 350°C, the inorganic-like carbons still remain, as ascertained by TPR-Q-mass analysis. The proposed deactivation mechanism would be consistent with other analytical evidences such as thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), CO adsorption, transmission electron micrograph (TEM) of used catalysts as well as NH3-TPD of the used zeolites.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of zeolite on the activity of Ru/MnCO3 catalysts for Fischer–Tropsch reaction
